{"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/police-does-start-ting/article_d6694e84-7648-5e6e-80a0-f003f40b4fdf.html", "TITLE": " Police does start 'ting' ", "DATE": "Jan 3, 2009 ", "CONTENT": "If you see Dean (not his real name), you wouldn't believe he is a drug dealer. An ordinary looking man with kind, intelligent eyes, he is an attentive father, quiet and calm, with an engaging smile. He runs his 'business' like a pro, organising shipments and distribution as well as any UWI management graduate. His home is clean and neat, the walls adorned with paintings and pictures from the Bible. He is a man who could be a councillor or MP for his area, given the concern he has for the people of his community. But that's not how life works - the ones who get into office, and become instruments of the 'system', quickly get used to the perks and the power, leaving the drug dealers to take care of the communities. Everybody wants to live nice. For some there are legitimate ways and means of doing so; others commit white-collar crimes and get away with it; while the bandits, gangsters, thugs, call them what you want, see the system as unjust and corrupt, and decide to play the game - their way. Crime is happening all over the world, in every country, on different levels. But the violence and brutality we are experiencing in Trinidad and Tobago right now is unprecedented in our short history as an independent state. We all know the different factors at play: guns and drugs coming from South America, open borders, billions of dollars flowing through the economy, corrupt officials and an ineffective police force. Add to this an uneducated, angry legion of men, both young and old, with no hope but plenty of ambition and the desire to be somebody, by any means necessary. In this crisis of hopelessness, finding one who would speak frankly and fearlessly about this way of life is a difficult task. The number one rule of the ghetto is to keep one's mouth shut. As they say in Jamaica, and as many have learnt the hard way in T&T, 'informer fi dead'. But those who live on the wrong side of the law in this country have another reason to keep quiet: they say the police are involved in the crime. This is Dean's claim. He agreed to speak to me only on condition of complete anonymity; if he could be identified in any way, he could certainly kiss his life, and even that of his family, goodbye. Dean was cagey, he chose his words with care. He related incidents that implicated police officers in the running of drug blocks and the importing of guns...deadly information. We present some of this information. Q: How long have you had your business About 10, 15 years. Q: Why did you choose to be what upstanding members of the society would call a criminal I doh want to do this, yuh know. But I living third and fourth lives because of what de police do me. So I reach a point now where I doh care and I just living. Q: How much (drugs) do you sell in, say, a week [Shakes his head] I cyah tell yuh dat. Dah's my personal business. Me ent want de police to know my business. Dese people will kill your family and ting. Q: You deal cocaine I doh deal wid dat at all. I never like that. Q: What would you do if weed was legalised I could do business, like run a store or something, some kind of business. If they legalise it, I stop right away. It ent go sell like how it selling now. Everybody go have it. Q: So why you don't do that now, start up a business, go legal [Shakes his head] Even to find a good location hard. And I need de money. I does help plenty people who ent have, make sure everybody eat. Q: You carry a gun [Pauses for a moment] De Bible say, if a man carry a gun, he have intention to kill. [Shakes his head] I not into that. Q: What is causing all the murder and gang warfare De police is de ones who does start ting. Is dem who does create de riot. I does deal wid everybody gang leaders, pushers, murderers. De police is de problem. I see a police vehicle coming to drop off the goods on a block. The block does deal weed, coke and guns. I watch that for weeks and months. And I say that ent right. I take myself and went to the police complainants [sic] building in town to tell them what going on. I meet the big man, he name __ ( name given), I never forget it. Next thing you know, about 28 police show up at my house with big guns and ransack the place. They cracking gun in my children face and cussing. But they ain't find nutten. Dey take me to kill me. I telling yuh. Dey carry me in de bush and beat me real bad. Is a bredren see me in de bush and save me. [He shows a scar where he was cut]. I get three lock-up after that, me and my family. Imagine they running block, doing worse than me. De people living in fear. We cyah go to dem. But I go have to take things in my own hands. Is only God protecting me right now. Q: So all this talk by the Police Commissioner about cracking down on crime is a pappy show Things real dread this time around. Police putting gun in man hand and sending them to do thing. Is dem control de gangs and dem. Yuh ent hear [acting Commissioner of Police James ] Philbert say he go talk to de gang leaders I hear him say that on TV a night. So dey know who is to be killed. Right now is a whole seta small gangs and these fellas need protection so de police does protect them. Listen, is de old heads who corrupt. Dem old police who running tings for years. They have dem in every station. You have young ones who might want to come out clean and do things different but is pressure for them. I does talk to them [young officers] and they ent want to do what de old ones telling them to do, but they have no choice. Dey under real pressure. Q: What about the guns - who bringing them in Is de police who does take boat and go down to de border and cut dey flick wid de Guardia. If a man manage to come through is because he ent pay he tax, and de Guardia does call [the T&T Coast Guard] and tell dem, Take he. He ent pay he tax. And dah's how yuh does hear man get hold, and dey report big bust and ting. Q: Is there a solution to crime If de police did know how to deal wid people, crime woulda done. It have people like me who know everybody in the area. I could tell them who is who. But they doh want to deal wid me. Dem is pure haters. People know what going on but they fraid to talk. They cyah trust de police because they going back and tell de same gang leaders. And de government ent doing nutten about it. Weed is not a criminal offence. Dey could fine yuh fuh it. But dey only locking up man who trying to hustle a living to feed he family. Dey put him in jail wid real criminals, murderers and tief. When he come out he looking to buy two gun and live life easy. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/no-real-progress-in-fighting-cases-of-crime-corruption/article_d5d53296-abce-5f01-a471-4827456009d5.html", "TITLE": " No real progress in fighting cases of crime, corruption ", "DATE": "Jan 10, 2014 ", "CONTENT": "Once again, crime is in deadly focus; once again, we have the slew of poorly thought-out, knee-jerk \"solutions\" such as hanging, one-strike, precepting the Army and so on being promoted as the way forward. Seems as though we haven't learned from the SoE (state of emergency) that these steps alone bring no lasting benefit. We then have the customary use of \"statistics\", meant to illustrate the progress being made, progress that we, of course, remain totally unconvinced of. And just in case that doesn't work, we have ideas such as \"criminals killing criminals\" and the need to \"bleed to heal\" being touted. Judging by the amount of blood that has been shed over the past decade, we should be living in paradise by now. As if that isn't enough, you have cut prices of flour and rice to grab our attention. In the midst of all, the causal factors behind a lot of our criminal activity remain largely unaddressed. The primary underlying cause is international organised crime, especially drug, weapons and human trafficking and their accompanying offences, such as money laundering, corruption of legal and law enforcement bodies and destruction of communities. What action has been taken to deepen co-operation with international agencies It seems we can't even have adequate co-operation between our local agencies. What is being done to secure our porous borders Has any tangible action been taken in relation to money laundering The key to reducing crime is taking the money out of it. Another way to reduce money in the hands of the underworld is to legalise certain activities and put proper controls in place. Why not take a serious look at legalising certain drugs, updating our immigration policies to encourage the people we need to come and keep the ones we don't want out, and, of course, revamping our legal and penal systems to place a greater focus on restorative justice. Running a close second to international organised crime is corruption, a most insidious activity that seems to become more entrenched with each successive administration. Corruption and wastage take away resources and focus that should be used to develop the country's infrastructure, to educate our people and to build our international profile. Recently, we have seen senior administration personnel partying hard with persons accused of serious financial crimes. Would they consort freely with persons accused of robbery, rape and murder The fact that this has occurred in the shadow of the Section 34 debacle is a slap in the face of the populace. This would probably be listed as yet another \"misstep\", but what is the number of missteps that equates to incompetence. The lack of real economic development across too many areas in this rich country is another significant causal factor of crime. And no, being the second or third-richest country in the Caribbean isn't outstanding economic development. With our natural resources, geographical position and human resources, it's almost a shame. That's like Usain Bolt coming second in an under-15 race. Various governments haven't even put in place anti-crime measures such as computerisation of the Licensing Office, providing police with needed tools and technology, streamlining the Police Service, empowering communities and ensuring an efficient and well-funded judiciary. Lots of gun talk, chest-thumping and little to no real progress on the anti-crime front. We deserve and must demand better. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/t-t-under-siege/article_c70b2cd2-6b20-524e-8932-431e8aea3b32.html", "TITLE": " T&T under siege ", "DATE": "Nov 24, 2011 ", "CONTENT": "CRIME in Trinidad and Tobago was yesterday in focus on episode 18 of Channel Four of the United Kingdom's Unreported World series where this country was branded \"the murder capital of the Caribbean\" and a major drug port. Filmed by Channel Four journalist Seyi Rhodes and director Will West during the 11 p.m. to 4 a.m. curfew period of the still-ongoing State of Emergency, much of yesterday's episode features 'hotspots' in Port of Spain like Laventille and environs of East Port of Spain. In it, Rhodes and West, who obtained a curfew pass for the period, followed local police on visits through Laventille, which they called a \"notoriously violent area\". They painted a picture of a country under siege with an 'anything goes' atmosphere, as they describe parallels of feting sprees by some and killing sprees by others. According to Channel Four, half a million tourists flock to Trinidad every year for Carnival but the country also deals with a mostly gang-related murder every hours. Channel Four also reported that more than 4,000 people have been held during the SoE, where the army and police can enter and search a property without a warrant. The episode mentioned Calvary Hill as being the scene of scores of murders, where gang culture and drug dealing have spiralled out of control in the last decade. The team also interviewed a Calvary Hill resident identified only as 'Susan', a mother who saw two of her sons arrested on gang-related charges and who said she did not believe the SoE will bring an end to violence. Nelson Street in downtown Port of Spain was also highlighted, where Rhodes reported that \"the drug dealing that has blighted this area is still going on, in spite of the police presence\". Trinidad is then called \"a smugglers paradise\", an island of inlets and coves whose proximity to Venezuela has made it a major transshipment point for drugs heading to North America and Europe from South America. Guns brought in by drug smugglers to protect their shipments also make it onto the streets, once the drugs are gone, Channel Four reported. Rhodes also reported, \"According to UN estimates, in 2004 smugglers paid nearly 80 million a year in bribes to Trinidadian officials.\" The team spoke with National Security Adviser Gary Griffith, whom they called one of the \"architects\" of the SoE and one of its most outspoken supporters. Yet, Rhodes reported that Griffith agreed with him that the State of Emergency is \"completely ineffective\" in dealing with top-level crime. Asked why the government is focused on the SoE and neighbourhood crackdowns, rather than corruption, Griffith said: \"Every single country in the world will have corrupt politicians, corrupt police officers and persons in the judiciary. We needed that to stop law-abiding citizens from being killed.\" Unreported World, as Rhodes tells it, has found that the SoE has not led to any fundamental changes and he concluded that \"until the government tackles official corruption and the drug transshipment industry, drugs and guns will leak onto Trinidad's streets and the murders will continue\". {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/police-and-thief/article_8869ef0f-4c7a-5e93-b30b-7709f0158331.html", "TITLE": " POLICE AND THIEF ", "DATE": "Oct 17, 2011 ", "CONTENT": "I went to the Carapichaima EC School until I was ten. Then I went to the Piccadilly EC School in East Dry River. Our favourite game as schoolchildren in Carapichaima was \"Police and Thief\". In Piccadilly, it was \"Rescue\". Looking at those days from the perspective of the present, I can clearly see how nave we were in Carapichaima to make, and believe there was, a distinction between the two occupations. In the old western movies which were the mainstay of the Carapichaima cinema (now a church), the \"Sheriff\" was different from the \"Head Crook\". Even when we switched sides, there was no blurring of identities. In fact, we all wanted to be \"Police\" and catch thieves. I suppose that is why \"Police and Thief\" was not played in Port of Spain. People in Piccadilly were well aware that there were no boundaries between police and thieves. In those days the requirements for recruitment into the police \"force\" were a school-leaving certificate and a \"godfather\". The brighter kids had already left school and were either at high school or working. Those who could not make it in the academic or occupational worlds were \"on the block\" for a long period. Some of them got involved in petty crime and, if not caught (and sometimes even if they were), ended up as policemen. This was a \"rescue\" of sorts. However, those who made it never lost touch with their other friends and if you ever go to a Magistrate's Court anywhere in Trinidad, it is clear that the police of all ranks are closer to, and care more for, the criminals than for the rest of us law-abiding citizens. My lessons came later in Siparia where the police shot a man in the Savannah who we knew was unarmed and who later mysteriously turned up with a \"revolver\" which was really a toy gun. But how were the poor police supposed to know that A Corporal, who lived a few houses down the street from us, used to take things from my father's small, struggling shop without paying. He later became a Deacon of the Anglican Church and an Assistant Commissioner of Police. This is why I am never surprised when the police commit or are accused of committing crimes, both major and petty. Last week two policemen were suspended for alleged involvement in the escape from the Point Fortin police station of two dangerous criminals accused of murder (something that has happened before in other stations); a policeman who questioned a magistrate's judgment was supposed to have ended up in a Golden Grove cell overnight but instead was taken to the hospital by his colleagues. Despite a State of Emergency, the trade in women from Colombia is still proceeding as the lagniappe cargo to drugs and guns. Two policemen are accused of demanding and taking money from a Police Inspector's relative to hush up a driving incident. The list is legion. The good news is that there is now a Police Complaints Authority headed by Gillian Lucky. The bad news is that persons who have previously complained or borne witness against policemen end up dead, missing or absent in court. Given that the Government says it will bring back Corporal Punishment, the best news would be if they also impose Constable, Sergeant, Inspector, Superintendent and even Commissioner punishment. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/joseph-better-days-coming/article_d6a54275-7360-5655-9dbb-747df8fc4907.html", "TITLE": " Joseph: Better days coming ", "DATE": "May 7, 2010 ", "CONTENT": "10.18 SECONDS: Emmanuel Callender 10.18 SECONDS: Emmanuel Callender National Security Minister Martin Joseph assured last night that there will be a dramatic reduction in this country's crime rate soon. Speaking at the PNM's public meeting in Point Fortin, Joseph explained that the reason there are currently high levels of crime was because of this country's location. He said Trinidad and Tobago is a major transshipment point between the drug-producing countries of South America and the drug- consuming countries of Europe and North America. He said the Government had invested a huge amount of taxpayers' dollars to acquire a 360 degree radar system and a fleet of vessels for the Coast Guard, so as to ensure those in the drug trade could be caught and found in our waters. As a result, this country now has the most number of marine assets ever seen in its history and still to come are three offshore patrol vessels. \"This Government is ensuring that we expand the Coast Guard's manpower to make sure the naval assets we require will ensure measures are put in place to reduce the inflow of drugs and guns coming into this country,\" Joseph said. \"And we can give you the assurance that once that is done, you can see a dramatic reduction in the level of crime and violence that continues to plague this country even now as we speak ... you have the assurance, it is not just ole talk, you have seen it manifested itself in terms of assets being acquired to make sure that we are going to address this problem,\" Joseph continued. Joseph added that to improve law enforcement, it was the PNM Government who brought legislation to give the Police Service Commission and Commissioner of Police more authority over the police. He said the police training academy has also been upgraded and the curriculum has been upgraded by expert help. He said Government also increased the number of police vehicles, adding that between 2002 and now, some 956 vehicles were purchased to bring the fleet up to 1425. \"We recognise and admit that crime is the number one issue. Those opposed to us want to make it the only issue, over the next two weeks they going to bombard you ... they go say Manning must go because of crime. Tell them they must go because your Government is putting measures in place to deal with crime,\" Joseph said. \"The war against illegal drugs and guns will continue in our next term ... your PNM government will not waiver, will not flinch from these responsibilities.\" He urged the people to find some quiet time and reflect on what the PNM government has done for this country before they go to vote on May 24. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/t-t-failed-cyon/article_648cc594-28fe-56e5-ba0a-a0e1eda6ce5d.html", "TITLE": " T&T failed Cyon ", "DATE": "Aug 27, 2016 ", "CONTENT": "A nine-year-old was gunned down; a bullet through the heart and the country continued its business as usual. Cyon Emmanuel Paul was fatally shot while he and his relatives were going to purchase food for his sister and himself. The agony and pain of Cyon's mother, Safiya Williams, can be felt in the image of her crying on the street where her son was murdered. What is even more heart-wrenching is the reality that Cyon's murder did not spark outrage and did not shake this country as it should. Whether it was said before or not, the reality is had Cyon been the son of a wealthy businessman, the son of a member of Government, the son of a foreigner, the son from a family of status, there would be calls for heads to roll, for no stone to be left unturned until his killer is brought to justice. Cyon is the son of a woman whose pain was splashed across the newspaper front page as she wept on the road, the spot where her son lost his life. \u201cThey have to stop this drug war, stop it now. Too many innocent people getting killed. Put down your guns. Drugs life don't pay.\u201d Safiya Williams was reported as saying. Her son's life was snuffed out, just short of his tenth birthday. Murder is murder regardless of the circumstances. Whether Cyon's death was a tragedy from gun, gang or drug warfare, at the end of the day, a young child is dead. Cyon was robbed of his life. When school reopens one week from today, his seat at the La Romaine Roman Catholic School will be empty. As a doctor I have delivered thousands of babies. The joy of holding a newborn, hearing his cry and taking his or her first breath of life is something that cannot be described. That baby is born with a purpose, with endless possibilities, vessels of hope. As a mother, I know a love that has no bounds, I've nurtured my children and watched them grow. Every day, every year is priceless and filled with so many amazing moments. The first step, the first words, the first day at school, the sweet curiosity, all beautiful memories to cherish for a lifetime. Imagine all that ending, with a single bullet. Have we as a nation become immune to the bloodshed Prime Minister Dr Keith Rowley asserted that he is in charge of the National Security Council and law enforcement is being provided with all the resources it needs to fight the criminal elements. Why, then, are they losing the war on crime National Security Minister Edmund Dillon was reported saying that just a handful of criminals, ten per cent, were responsible for wreaking havoc on our nation and he called on police to make their lives miserable and not allow them to live in comfort. Sadly, it is the people in this country who are now paralysed with fear and living in discomfort. Where is safe today if a child can be killed by a stray bullet while going to purchase food So afraid are we that patients are now scheduling planned deliveries to avoid being on the streets at night. A few weeks ago, police presence was very noticeable on the highways when the speed guns came into the country. There was a grand show on how many speeding motorists were caught, and drivers were actually observing the speed laws. It was good while it lasted. Now, it seems the cops, like a kid with a new toy, have grown tired of the devices as their absence is noticeable and all caution by drivers is thrown to the wind. It sends the message that all the great plans and initiatives that are implemented in the crime fight are possibly not followed through long term. Gun-toting criminals are walking around unafraid because even if they are caught, our criminal justice system is like a monopoly game where you can get out of jail fast. The system is rotten and failing on different levels. Detection is poor, conviction and prosecution is poor and prevention is basically in the hands of citizens to protect themselves and their families by living under lock and key. But the criminals are even terrorising people in their homes. Nowhere is safe. As the new school term reopens I hope to see an increased police presence on the streets, many of our children commute and rely on public transport and they should be able to return to their homes safely without encountering the same tragedy as Cyon. There is no simple solution to fighting crime but when red blood flows freely, it is common sense there would be more blue lights around. In a release, the CCIC, headed by Chamber president Richie Sookhai, commended the United States Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) on unearthing cocaine valued at US$100 million (TT$644m) in cans bearing the SM Jaleel Co Ltd labels of Trinidad Orange and Grapefruit juices and seized in Norfolk, Virginia in the United States. The CCIC stated that while praise is justly due for the work of foreign security entities, this issue emphasises the lack of or improper enforcement of this country's own security apparatus. \"The fact that millions of dollars of cocaine can leave this country packaged as canned juice is evident that something is wrong. This drug bust is embarrassing for Trinidad and Tobago and is a further blow to international investor confidence which is slipping daily as the big fish or fishes remain free,\" said Sookhai. \"The CCIC is alarmed that such a large quantity of illegal drugs can easily be moved from our borders without a trace and the question arises as to how long this has been happening undetected and whether the problem is of crisis proportions as it relates to human trafficking, especially of women and children,\" he added. Soohai stated that the Chamber was deeply concerned about the level of crime that continues to grip this country and the worrying trend of a low detection rate. \"National Security ministers, both past and present, have publicly stated that this country is a transhipment hub where drugs and guns enter our communities and into the hands of our youth fuelling gang warfare. It is time for action,\" stated the release. The CCIC issued a call for the People's Partnership Government and the relevant authorities to ensure that our borders are guarded, both land and sea. It noted that billions of taxpayers' money was spent on the crime fight over the past decade and questioned what was there to show for it. According to Sookhai, technology must be instrumental in the war against crime and high-tech scanners and radar machines such as those used in the US must be implemented. \"A simple measure such as the use of sniffer dogs at our airports and ports can go a long way in detecting the movement of illegal substances,\" stated the release. The CCIC said a holistic approach was needed where various bodies work together to combat the crime scourge. \"Where are the regulatory bodies and law enforcement agencies e.g. Customs, banks and the Financial Intelligence Agency (FIU) These are institutions that were supposed to be sharing information and yet no one was able to identify any suspicious transaction,\" it stated. The CCIC advised that citizens play their role in the crime fight and make reports to the police. \"The CCIC also calls on the people of the nation to be thy neighbour's keeper and while the Chamber urges everyone to guard themselves, remember your civic duty and report any illegal activities.\" TWO videos which show minors engaged in sexual acts with adults are now engaging the attenti\u2026 The prisoner who escaped from the Maximum Security Prison on Thursday, has been found. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/caricom-seeks-to-track-guns-ammo-in-region/article_c535b0af-92dd-5892-a88f-47e3cdf81cd7.html", "TITLE": " Caricom seeks to track guns, ammo in region ", "DATE": "Feb 9, 2011 ", "CONTENT": "crime influx: Dr Errol Cort crime influx: Dr Errol Cort A central unit geared towards identifying the origins of firearms and ammunition within the Caribbean will be established within the next three years, Antigua and Barbuda Minister of National Security and Labour Dr Errol Cort says. Cort made the statement while delivering the feature address at Wednesday's project launch, entitled \"Strengthening Caricom Co-operation to Reduce Gun Crime\", at the Hilton Trinidad in St Ann's. Among those in attendance were National Security Minister Brigadier John Sandy, executive director of the Caricom Implementation Agency for Crime and Security (Impacs), Lynne Anne Williams, Commissioner of Police Dwayne Gibbs and representatives of the Canadian High Commission. \"On the heels of this launch, it is also anticipated that the region will see the initiation of the Regional Integrated Ballistic Information Network (RIBIN). RIBIN will be used to identify the \"fingerprint\" of the ammunition used in a crime and to record the details of the firearm used. This will further complement one of the objectives of the project to effectively document information pertaining to small arms and light weapons,\" Cort said. Cort said the region has not been silent amidst calls to reduce the demand for and the supply of illegal drugs, but \"with the assistance of the European Union and through Caricom Impacs, the Caricom Regional Demand Reduction and Caricom Capacity Building Programme for Law Enforcement, member states have benefitted from both training and upgrades\". Adding the Caribbean community has an influx of organised crime and gang-related activities, Cort said these activities are spawned through drug-trafficking, \"which are accompanied by high levels of homicide, in which illegal guns feature more than 70 per cent of the time\". Counsellor for the High Commission of Canada to T&T, Laurent Morel-a-l'Huissier, who also spoke, said approximately $12 million is being spent on the three-year project. \"This project, which is being undertaken through a partnership involving Caricom Impacs, Project Ploughshares, the Institute of International Relations at the University of the West Indies (UWI) and Caribbean civil society organisations, was conceptualised from a mutual commitment to control the illicit proliferation and misuse of small arms in the Caribbean. Guns are frequently traded between countries in exchange for drugs, food and appliances,\" Morel-a-l'Huissier said. \"It is not unreasonable to expect the possibility and high probability, for one gun to be used to commit crime in one member state then show up at one or more crime scenes in other member states.\" Morel-a-l'Huissier said the project will be implemented through a partnership between Canadian-based NGOs and Caricom. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/outgunned/article_32fcfc7e-18f5-5edd-a606-f369897fee40.html", "TITLE": " OUTGUNNED ", "DATE": "Sep 10, 2013 ", "CONTENT": "FIRE POWER: Gangsters brandish new high-tech guns in the Laventille area in late June. FIRE POWER: Gangsters brandish new high-tech guns in the Laventille area in late June. GANGSTERS are brandishing far superior high-tech weapons than the police and other law enforcement agencies in this country. Photographs obtained by TV6s news investigative team from well-placed intelligence sources show three young men posing with these weapons. Two of the men are holding two of the guns in their hands, while the next man with a thick gold chain is holding one in his hand. In another photograph the man with the gold chain is sitting on a rock and has two guns on his lap and two in his hands. All the guns in the picture appear spanking new. These photographs were taken in late June this year in the Laventille area and have raised major concerns in law enforcement circles as they grapple with the homicide rate that has escalated in this area in the last two months. Sources at the police Crime and Problem Analysis Branch said at least 85 per cent of the homicides for the year are gun-related. The reason for this mounting concern is the firepower that these gangsters are packing. The guns in the pictures are no ordinary guns. They are in fact AR-15 guns. This semi-automatic weapon in the hands of proven criminals can do serious damage. Allison Hamilton, assistant secretary of the Trinidad Rifle Association, who has expertise about these weapons shared his insight. What I know is that they are used by the US army and a lot of other armies around the world so they are serious weapons of war. For weapons like that to be in the hands of people on the street is a frightening situation. The AR-15s firing capacity lives up to its menacing appearance. This semi-automatic weapon fires one round per pull of the trigger before reloading itself. So while it cannot unleash a hail of bullets like a fully automatic weapon, it can fire as quickly as the gunman can pull the trigger. This was in fact the exact weapon used by alleged shooter James Holmes in the Colorado theatre shooting at the premiere of the Dark Knight on July 20 last year in which 12 people were killed and more than 70 injured. We have tangible evidence to suggest the gangsters in the hills of Laventille are using these weapons to zone in on targets in the East Port of Spain area, the source said. Residents along Nelson and Duncan Streets also claim that while they are out in the yard among the buildings they are shot at, and even showed bullet hole impressions left in the walls. Children are playing here sometimes and they start to shoot at us, said one woman who didnt want to be named. Several gun experts online describe this weapon as rugged, reliable, portable and accurate. Intelligence police sources say gangsters here use two different types of ammunition with the AR-15, with either one having deadly consequences. The .556 have something like a .22 projectile and .762 have something like a 9mm projectile, the effective distance of the .762 is a lot further than the .556 but both are equally damaging to its target,explained Hamilton. The fragmentation of these ammunition can do greater damage to humans internally, travelling at a higher velocity, Hamilton pointed out. We showed the photographs of the high powered rifles to acting Police Commissioner Stephen Williams who appeared taken aback by the weapons. Those weapons hitting the streets of Trinidad and Tobago also provide this kind of shocking impact to me having to lead an organisation where my officers are out there and have to be confronted with that kind of fire power by criminal elements, he said. A testimony to the Commissioners words came in May this year following the John John protests. Intelligence sources revealed to TV6 News that gangsters warned police not to venture up the tracks and other areas since they would be sniped by shooters. To date, according to Williams, the police have recovered 232 firearms and though he views this as a high number, in his books it is still not enough. In fact, in police gun seizures for the year they never once came upon a weapon like the AR-15,Williams indicated. Intelligence sources are convinced these specific weapons are not only coming from South America but also directly from the USA, since these kind of weapons can be easily broken down and concealed for shipment. The mere fact that the police arent able to find these guns is worrisome and terrifying said the top cop. The critical thing when we look at weapons like those is about getting them off the streets because weapons like those could hurt this country big time, the flow of blood which can be generated through the use of anyone of those weapons could be massive and disastrous, said Williams as he shifted uneasily in his chair. But the question really is how these guns are getting into the country and whats the deal on the streets Williams said they are planning to tighten up security at the sea ports and airports as they attempt to clamp down on contraband entering the country. But one crime boss along the East West corridor speaking to us on the condition that he concealed his identity, did not sugar coat his underworld dealings with guns,drugs and other nefarious activities. We have AR-15s, AKs, nines we dealing with. We dont sell our gun, that is to protect we self and we turf. Inset: Crime Scene experts view the victim's car. \u0097Photos: ANISTO ALVES Quick action: Officers from the Western Division Task Force prepare to conduct a search in Richplain, Diego Martin, yesterday, after the fatal shooting of Camille Daniel in the courtyard of the West End Police Station. Inset: Crime Scene experts view the victim's car. \u0097Photos: ANISTO ALVES THE WEST End Police Station in Diego Martin, the scene of yesterday's horrific murder and also one of the five model police stations in the country, was voted by residents as making the area safer, National Security Minister Martin Joseph says. Speaking at yesterday's Senate sitting, Joseph disclosed that a survey was conducted by consultant Roger D Parkes to examine the reaction of the people to the five model stations located in West End, Morvant, Arouca, Chaguanas and San Fernando. Joseph said model police stations were introduced to change the way in which police do business. These stations, he noted, are more equipped with resources and also officers. He said some 3000 persons were surveyed between January 3 and March 16 this year, and it was found that residents felt safer with the increased police presence and model stations. \"You are seeing a change ... not as rapid as we would like to see, but the seeds have been planted and you are going to be seeing an improvement in some of the areas,\" Joseph said. Joseph also took the opportunity to defend the $80 million Mastrofski initiative to transform the police service. He pointed out that large sums of money are expended to run the police service and some $1.3 billion was spent last year. \"The investment in bringing someone to help identify what is necessary to transform the police service is an investment well spent,\" he said. He also spoke of the Government's heavy investment in Coast Guard vessels, giving the assurance that with a full functioning naval fleet, the drugs and guns flowing into this country would be stemmed. Joseph added that although the murder rate had surpassed the rates in 2007 and 2008, the level of detection had increased slightly. He noted that in 2008, the detection rate from January 1 to June 23 was 18.8 per cent and for this year there was a slight increase to 21.7 per cent. Acknowledging the endless calls for his resignation, Joseph said the transformation of the police service and the effect of all the initiatives of the Government would take time to reap results. Admitting that the process was taking longer than expected, he said Government will continue to build the capacity of law enforcement not just for now but for the future. \"We are going to continue to provide the resources and ensure all law enforcement agencies are provided with the resources necessary so that this war against crime can in fact be won,\" he said. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/we-can-begin-crime-battle-by-becoming-disciplined/article_622e3043-7b48-585e-95e6-578ffb40a542.html", "TITLE": " We can begin crime battle by becoming disciplined ", "DATE": "May 21, 2013 ", "CONTENT": "In order to confront the crime situation in our country, it is necessary to analyse the underlying cause of the situation before embarking on an overall solution to contain this runaway disease. I maintain that the underlying cause of this endemic problem which has hitherto remained unsolved is the complete breakdown of discipline in the whole country and in every walk of life. It therefore cannot be solved by any one ministry. There has to be a united effort of the various ministries of the government throughout the Public Service. The Education Ministry, for example, must get together to make a national onslaught on the runaway crime situation. Discipline must return to the schools and all public institutions, the Public Service as a whole must become less corruptible and be more service oriented. The Police Service must rid itself of the rogue elements with strong punitive measures against errant police officers. Teachers must instill a sense of fairplay and discipline in the schools, backed up by the ministry and the Teaching Service Commission. The Ministry of Transport must institute strong measures to curb the reckless driving and the breaking of the traffic laws all over the country. In the homes, parents must take an active part in the welfare and upbringing of their children and set an example of good behaviour among their charges. Truant officers should be appointed to ensure every child of school age attends school. The drug trade must be curtailed by not only increasing the penalties for possession and using but all fishing ports must be manned by army and police officers to ensure drugs are not brought in or taken out of the country. The possession of illegal firearms must be punishable by life imprisonment and confiscation of all properties. At the same time, citizens with properties to protect should all be given guns for their own protection and the law of justifiable homicide adopted. There are many more actions which could be taken and more thought must be given to arrest the crime endemic in our twin island state. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/deyalsingh-govt-has-failed-miserably-in-crime-fight/article_2305aa29-4829-5218-ab61-bee7fb37043a.html", "TITLE": " Deyalsingh: Govt has failed miserably in crime fight ", "DATE": "Apr 3, 2013 ", "CONTENT": "GET SERIOUS; Terrence Deyalsingh GET SERIOUS; Terrence Deyalsingh THE CURRENT Government has been \"soft\" on the wholesale side of crime such as importers of drugs, human trafficking and arms trafficking, said Opposition Senator Terrence Deyalsingh. He referred to the incident in September 2011 when a shipping container of chicken parts \"seasoned with marijuana\" was discovered at the Point Lisas port. He noted the Government and National Security Ministry had announced 23 initiatives to tackle crime including an advisory council...aerial surveillance, strengthening of the Police Service, dedicated highway patrol unit, regulation of private security industry and maritime security. \"Almost none of those things has been done. But we keep on passing laws,\" he said. He continued: \"I think from the last administration to this one, we should realise by now that passing laws targets crime at the retail end. The little boy with the gun and the rock of cocaine are not the importers.\" He said the country needed to get serious about protecting our borders but this administration has \"failed miserably\" cancelling the Offshore Patrol Vessels and using the associated helicopters for personal use. He noted the previous People's National Movement administration gave this Government a national security apparatus \"on a silver platter\" and \"you did nothing with it\". Deyalsingh was contributing to the Senate debate on Tuesday night on the Miscellaneous Provisions (Defence and Police Complaints) Bill at Tower D, International Waterfront Centre, Port of Spain. Deyalsingh pointed out that police officers with all their training and years of experience at times misapply the judge's rules (guidelines about police and questioning and the acceptability of the resulting statements and confessions as evidence in court) leading to cases collapsing. He predicted that when soldiers, who lack that institutional learning, are detaining and arresting people more cases could be thrown out. He also questioned whether a soldier would appreciate the suspect's constitutional rights and would they be trained in police procedure and in these rights also. He said the legislation would create a \"bifurcation\" as there would be a duality of recording of informationthe soldier and the police officerand there would be ambiguity and blurred lines of responsibility as the soldiers would not know which superior officer to obey. Deyalsingh predicted that the groups currently supporting the legislation, like the Downtown Owners and Merchants Association and the Chamber of Commerce, would only realise it was wrong after it was implemented. In the course of that column I referred yet again to the impunity with which murder and other crimes are committed and had a bit of a sardonic smile that it has taken so many so long to see that the impunity factor was at the heart of our crisis. The column also reflected yet again on the lack of political will and on law enforcement failure to disrupt the drug trade, which have bred and maintained the impunity factor. This is what I wrote in May 2003: \u201cWe must pressure the Government, whoever they are, to take back control of the resources of the State from cronies and pardners, armed or unarmed. That is a political job. It is not the job of the police. Their job is to attack first, and with urgency and integrity, the drug trade that underlies the gang murders\u201d. That column published 13 years ago continued: \u201cIf any Government does not act independently of the criminal element in the society, whether they are grassroots bandits or the 'devils in disguise' in our Westwood Parks, the regulation of society in the interest of the common good will eventually become impossible. The laws of the land will have legal validity but will cease to be effective.\u201d It must be clearly understood that law enforcement failure is not a failure of the police alone. It includes the Coastguard, the Customs and the Inland Revenue, the latter being able to strike by assessments of conspicuous consumption. The Judiciary also has a responsibility to increase the speed of the delivery of criminal justice beyond \u201cworking like molasses running uphill\u201d. The molasses comparison comes from a recent editorial in the Barbados Nation newspaper. Earlier this month Barbados was thrown into a state of shock when a drug trade operative was gunned down at the entrance to a restaurant, and within the compound of the busiest area in Warrens, the Massy complex. The security camera video of the shooting was released. In the words of the editorial: \u201cThere was no need for a single Barbadian to speculate or gossip about what occurred. In living colour, the world saw the killers and the victim, the multiple flashes from the muzzles of the guns, and the deliberateness of the murderers as they carried out their execution. Commenting on another shooting, the editorial pointed out the obvious wider danger: \u201cTaken with the reports of the apparent use of AK-47 assault rifles during the gunplay at Wotton, we do not believe that under the circumstances, many people will apply much weight to the oft-offered suggestions that ordinary Barbadians need not worry since these shootings and resultant deaths really relate to members of the underworld settling scores.\u201d Readers will recall reference a few weeks ago to reports of a former Attorney General and Chief Justice of Barbados, Sir David Simmons, having spoken on Barbados radio about the dangers of politicians \u201clying in bed with the underworld\u201d. As indicated then, Sir David was reported as saying that \u201cthroughout the Caribbean, especially Trinidad and Jamaica, there was evidence which showed political parties embraced gang leaders and drug lords\u201d including politicians involving those criminals in State-funded projects Forgive me therefore if I regard all current talk about co-operation on legislation as largely irrelevant. Tinkering with bail, the jury system and the laws of evidence are plasters for a big, in your face, running sore, which can be curtailed only by an all out bi-partisan attack on the drug trade and on corruption facilitated by the out of control state enterprise and statutory authority system and sawatee Chairpersons. The State enterprise/statutory authority system also masks incompetence and undermines accountability. For example, a Minister of Sport refers the media for answers to the SPORTT Company. It is massively ironic that there is now controversy about occupation of lands in the Chaguaramas peninsula. The Barbados gun-down took place just before the opening of the Barbados law term. Ours opened two days ago. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/are-we-serious-about-fighting-crime/article_15470457-b867-5f54-b925-6072582660fb.html", "TITLE": " Are we serious about fighting crime ", "DATE": "Sep 8, 2013 ", "CONTENT": "Bringing crime under control in T&T is as elusive as the proverbial pot of gold at the end of a rainbow. Governments, national security ministers and police commissioners have changed over the years with no significant effect on crime, especially murders. Arising out of a spike in murders over the last three weeks, the Prime Minister and the Opposition Leader finally met and agreed on certain initiatives to address the problem. In addition, the PM installed Gary Griffith as the new National Security Minister, that being the highlight of the ministerial reshuffle. These events play out like a recurring decimal \u2013 desperate reactions to appease the public when murders skyrocket. The leaders/politicians of this land are educated and must know the requirements to effectively address the crime dilemma. So why are only feeble attempts made to contain crime rates and restore law and order Are our leaders serious about fighting crime or more interested in nepotism, cronyism, serving themselves and \"mudslinging\" their opponents Note that the PM's most recent appeal to the Opposition to work together was rejected by Dr Rowley \u2013 another indication that the love for power trumps addressing the needs of the people. We can be sure that his prior pronouncement on working with the Government to control crime was a mere farce. The authorities know that guns, ammunition and drugs literally flood certain coastal areas. So a few marine vessels and helicopters were purchased some time ago to show the public that something is being done to eradicate, if not, curtail this illegal influx via our shores. With T&T's coastline length being 362 km or 225 miles and with the continuation of murders via shootings the public is aware that not nearly enough is being done to arrest the thriving illegal importation of guns and ammunition. The death penalty is cited as a deterrent for murder, yet the Government and Opposition continue to play \"footsie\" with the issue, as the label \"Death Row\" is a joke. Prisoners sent there generally have their death sentences commuted to life imprisonment. This lack of enforcement indicates to criminals and would-be murderers that the law is not to be feared \u2013 it's a joke. Apart from the lack of law enforcement, high crime rates are aided by insufficient law enforcers. But although a significant number of citizens apply to the Police Service, only a fraction appear to meet the required standards. So when crime spikes the army is called out to assist. It is obvious that a more permanent solution must be employed. Has serious consideration been given to making the job of a police officer more attractive, or at least attractive enough to woo more suitable applicants In the area of crime prevention, the Government's basketball tournament among specific communities was a good incentive that needs to be maintained and even broadened. More tournaments will create more sporting goals and less time for idleness and crime. Part of our problem is the lack of support for ideas/plans that work. If the authorities are serious about fighting crime, prisoners not consigned to Death Row must be afforded more rehabilitative incentives to curb recidivism. A serious approach to fighting crime must also include a speedy process for court matters and related sentencing, disbursements, etc. This plan must also ensure fairness to all people regardless of social status, race, skin colour, sexual orientation and political persuasion. We, the average citizens, must play our critical role too, as many of us flaunt the law at every opportunity. Driving with a cellphone at our ears and running red traffic lights are examples. Still, there is a perception that many folks would provide more information on crime to the police when a certain level of trust is restored. It appears that more co-operation from the public is dependent, to some extent, on the rooting out of rogue law enforcers from the system. Every sensible Trinbagonian knows the effective measures that, if implemented, can make citizens feel safe again. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/offshore-lockdown/article_91247faf-01cb-5c0e-857f-65100aab8fd1.html", "TITLE": " Offshore lockdown ", "DATE": "Sep 17, 2013 ", "CONTENT": "There will be a maritime lock-down within the year to prevent the inflow of drugs and guns into this country, says National Security Minister Gary Griffith. In his contribution to debate on the national budget, the recently appointed Minister said that the lock-down will not entail the use of three Offshore Patrol Vessels (OPVs) but one long range patrol vessel which was all that was required to secure the countrys economic zone from 12 to 200 miles. In addition, Griffith said that eight fast patrol vessels will be acquired to protect Trinidad and Tobagos waters from the border to two miles. He said the second tier involved the use of naval vessels which will complement the operations of the fast patrol interceptor vessels. Griffith stressed that a lock-down can only be effective if there is proper communication through an operations centre where all arms of law enforcement can work together. He said the national security operations centre will be implemented to provide that operational link between the police, army, coast-guard, air guard and other arms of law enforcement. Griffith said that the police and other authorities must be given the tools that they require to successfully combat crime and while there are some rogue elements the hard-working officials must be respected for their efforts. The Minister also disclosed that within the last year over 250 firearms were seized including 68 revolvers, 115 pistols, 19 shot guns, 3 sub machine guns, 9 rifles, 37 home made guns and 6 trap guns. He disclosed further that over $80 million in marijuana was seized by the organised crime narcotics and firearms bureau. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/m-in-ganja-found-in-banana-boxes/article_51b0da8c-8f5b-550d-9d58-f552555767e4.html", "TITLE": " $.3m in ganja found in banana boxes ", "DATE": "Feb 25, 2014 ", "CONTENT": "OFFICERS of the Port Police Task Force on Tuesday intercepted a vehicle exiting the Port of Port of Spain carrying marijuana valued at $300,000 hidden inside boxes filled with bananas. According to police reports, around 2 p.m. on Tuesday, officers of the Task Force noticed two men acting suspiciously as they off-loaded boxes from a vessel docked at the Caricom Open Wharf. The vessel is said to have arrived from St Vincent. The officers allowed the men to unpack their cargo. As the men tried to exit the port in a car, however, they were stopped near the Tobago ferry terminal. The vehicle was searched and some 24 kilogrammes of marijuana were found stuffed inside 18 banana boxes with false bottoms. The driver of the vehicle and its lone passenger are currently being held at the Central Police Station. The duo, aged 35 and 38, are expected to appear before a Port of Spain magistrate today. The seizure was made by Cpl Joseph and PCs Sookoo, Ashby and Sinanan, of the Port Police Task Force. The seizure by the Port Police Task Force comes one day after a $107 million marijuana eradication exercise in Biche. Speaking to the Express by telephone yesterday, National Security Minister Gary Griffith applauded the efforts of all this countrys law enforcement officials in the fight against crime and ridding the streets of guns and drugs. Griffith said the collaborative efforts of this countrys law enforcement officials have resulted in several key drug and gun busts. He said last month one of the highest levels of gun seizures was reported. On December 20 last year, Customs and Border Protection officers seized 732 pounds of cocaine, valued at US$100 million, concealed in cans bearing the labels of Trinidad Orange and Grapefruit juices at the Port of Norfolk in Virginia, USA. Griffith said local law enforcement was able to help in the seizure of 800 kilogrammes of cocaine seized off Azores by the Spanish Guardia on the sailing yacht Bucannero. The value of this seizure was three times that of the DEA bust and valued at US$300 million. He said local law enforcement was also integral in the seizure in 310 kilogrammes of cocaine by French Customs on the sailing yacht Blue Eye in Martinique. The value of that bust was US$100 million. He said the country can expect more busts to come, as citizens have started to show confidence in local law enforcement to treat with their tips. We have many more hits that will take place soon, and this has to do with what I call HUMIT, human intelligence. It is assisting us in trying to get the information we need and it is assisting the law-enforcement agencies greatly towards successful operations, Griffith said. He called on citizens to get behind local law enforcement. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/rowley-told-of-machine-gun-murders/article_29dbec76-ab3f-5f1f-9dce-a0d21c68d169.html", "TITLE": " Rowley told of machine gun murders ", "DATE": "Apr 2, 2017 ", "CONTENT": "Pocketed by bullets, the front wall of the home of Joel LePlatte who was killed in front of his house on Mon Coco Road, Maraval last Thursday night along with two friends. Photo: STEPHEN DOOBAY Pocketed by bullets, the front wall of the home of Joel LePlatte who was killed in front of his house on Mon Coco Road, Maraval last Thursday night along with two friends. Photo: STEPHEN DOOBAY On the night of the machine gun murders of three men in Maraval last Thursday, Prime Minister Dr Keith Rowley was contacted in Houston, Texas and informed of the bloodshed in his capacity as head of the National Security Council. This was disclosed last Thursday by Attorney General Faris Al Rawi during a press briefing at the Ministry of National Security, Abercromby Street, Port of Spain. Al-Rawi was supported by Minister of National Security Edmund Dillon, and acting Commissioner of Police, Stephen Williams. Al-Rawi said: \u201cI was in communication with the Prime Minister while he was aboard, up to about 1 a.m as the members of the National Security Council tracked closely the ongoing situation with respect to crime in Trinidad and Tobago . Last night the country witnessed in Le Platte Village, innocent bystanders caught in what appears to be machine gun fire, where the allegation is that a well known criminal was targeted and executed. And so indiscriminate was the action, that it didn't matter to anyone who was carrying out the crime that innocent by standers would be caught. As a government we warned in the past in parliament that it only takes one person with a machine gun to change the murder statistic in a horrible way overnight. and this is where we are,\u201d Al-Rawi said. The killings claimed the lives of Kaundi Critchlow, 24, Collins Letren, 25, and Joel Le Platte, 35, Link with drug busts The Attorney General said that from his information, there was an increase in gang activities in the country due to the amount of drugs being seized in recent months. \u201cThere is an obvious correlation between the amount of interdiction done re drugs and the effect that it is going to have with those who are deprived of the profit of the trade. Someone in T&T lost $837 million worth of product when 4.3 tonnes of cocaine was interdicted. Someone in T&T lost money when marijuana was interdicted in the Caribbean Sea, so the correlation is obvious,\u201d Al-Rawi said. Dillon and Williams expressed similar sentiments, saying that the incidents have put special focus on the need for the Police Service and the Government to put in a collaborative effort to deal with the explosion of violence which has been reported over the past month, especially in the Central Division, the Northern Division, and the Western Division. Dillon said the State will be working on all fronts to ensure that an operational and legislative approach was taken to tackle crime and gang related activities in these districts. The Minister also lamented that the lack of Opposition support for the Anti Gang and Bail Act, which was defeated in July 2016, had hindered the police's ability to seek out gang members and gang-related activity, so the Police Service no longer had power to make arrests without warrants, conduct searches of persons believed to be affiliated with gangs, and hold these persons for 120 days. Williams supported Dillon's comments, noting that without the backing of appropriate legislation, the hands of the police service were tied. \u201cI hear the discussion about the police service enforcing the gang law in the public domain but there seems to be an important part of that discussion missing- that there are no gang laws in Trinidad and Tobago to date. This part of the discussion seems to be lost. As it is right now, T&T is one of the few countries in the region without legislation in addressing a dedicated problem which everybody in this country is aware of,\u201d Williams said. However, despite the \u201chandicap\u201d, Williams assured that the Police Service would be taking a \u201chard\u201d approach against criminality in this country, and will do everything within their power to ensure the prosecution of persons caught committing illegal activities. THE SHOOTINGS According to police reports, on Thursday night, Critchlow, Letren, and Le Pllatte, were all liming along the roadway with a group of people, including cousins Dominique Le Platte and Dayna Le Platte. At about 7.30 p.m., a black motor vehicle pulled outside the group and a man was seen pointing what appeared to be a firearm in the direction of the group. There was a brief exchange of words, following which several loud explosions were then heard, in rapid succession. The vehicle and its armed assailants then sped off. When the dust settled, five persons were said to have received gunshot injuries, while three others were said to have received superficial injuries. The police and emergency health services were notified and a team of officers from the Western Division and the Homicide Bureau responded. Letren and Critchlow died on the scene. Joel Le Platte had suffered gunshot injuries to his head, left wrist and right thigh. As a result, he was rushed to the Port of Spain General Hospital where he was treated. However, doctors were unable to operate on the 35-year-old man as the hospital did not have a functioning CT Scanner to locate the bullet. As a result the wounded man was transferred to the Eric Williams Medical Sciences complex where he was examined. There, instructions were given to return Le Platte to the General Hospital. The 35-year-old man died minutes after returning to the Port of Spain Hospital, police said. Cousins Dominique Le Platte, and Dayna Le Platte, received no life threatening gunshot injuries. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/guns-here-to-stay/article_b9185d45-c7e5-5ec1-a5f0-2ac04169e20e.html", "TITLE": " GUNS HERE TO STAY ", "DATE": "Jan 2, 2010 ", "CONTENT": "Eastern Port of Spain has been labelled as \"among the most dangerous places on the planet\" by an international research body that tracks the growth of small arms and crime. In its report dated December 31, 2009, the Small Arms Survey of Switzerland explored the rise of criminal gangs and gangster-styled killings in Trinidad and Tobago and concluded the country's gun problems were not going to go away. The 53-page report is entitled ''No Other LifeGangs, Guns and Governance in Trinidad and Tobago.\" It opens with the tale of known gangster and sometimes political golden boy Sean \"Bill\" Francis who was gunned down last year, his body riddled with 50 bullets. This section of the report, says the author, Dorn Townsend, is meant to \"set the scene\". Townsend paints a grim picture of a wealthy but corrupt, segregated and generally \"out-of-its-league\" island nation that appears to be falling before even reaching grace. Stating in the paper's executive summary that gun-related homicides have increased 1,000-fold in the last decade, Townsend goes on in the next chapter to recall at the start of the 21st century, T&T was pegged to be the jewel of the Caribbean, a haven of relative stability. \"That is no longer the case,\" he said. The report is based on information garnered from various local sources, including the media, police, university professors and non-governmental organisations. \"This scene is not so much a 'war zone' as a 'Wild West', and it is no exaggeration to say that poor urban areas of Trinidad, in particular, have become magnets for lawlessness as rival gangs vie for control of territory where drugs are sold,\" the report said. Townsend said the explosion of this type of crime occurred during a period of unparalleled economic development and that up to the 2008/2009 economic downturn, T&T enjoyed one of the steadiest economic growth rates in the world. \"Overwhelmingly,\" Townsend stated, \"the violence is occurring among the country's poor, urban, African rather that its Indian or Caucasian residents. Primarily, city blacks are the victims.\" The report refers to or focuses, in several instances, on places known locally as hot spots, such as Laventille and Gonzales, and mentions efforts by legitimate community and church leaders to bring peace to these areas. Yet, Townsend stated: \"T&T's society though small in size is significantly complex, such that as a variety of forces stand arrayed against efforts at improvement.\" Exploring the alleged and known relationships between political leaders and gang leaders, Townsend stated: \"Also arrayed, or covertly arrayed, against such pressures for stability are the leaders of political parties who cultivate goodwill with gangs.\" And concluded: \"The above progressive and retrogressive forces are only suggestive of what is unfolding with regard to gangs and guns in T&T. Other markers of the problems may be brought to the fore. In turn, concerned stakeholders may develop a viable strategy for peace while controlling elements of the violent status quo. \"In any event, the national's problems of guns is not going to go away. Steps by the government to bolster law enforcement and curb smuggling are hobbled by a worsening of civic attitudes, ie citizens are downright cynical about the ability of the State to reverse the mayhem caused by guns and gangs.\" The Small Arms Survey is an independent research project located at the Graduate Institute of International and Developmental Studies in Geneva, Switzerland. It was established in 1999 and is supported by the Swiss Federal Department of Foreign Affairsn while being sustained by contributions from the governments of Belgium, Canada, Finland, Germany, the Netherlands, Norway, Sweden and the UK. The project's objective is, among others, to serve as the principal source of public information on all aspects of small arms and armed violence, as a resource centre for governments, policy-makers, researchers and activists, to monitor national and international initiatives (governmental and non) on small arms. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/us-report-drug-control-in-t-t-weak/article_07e7d108-1a37-590a-a531-091a37ab4f1a.html", "TITLE": " US report: Drug control in T&T weak ", "DATE": "Feb 28, 2009 ", "CONTENT": "Trinidad and Tobago lacks effective legislation to fight drug smuggling and crime, the United States State Department has said in its latest International Drug Control Strategy Report for 2008. \"Drug interdictions in Trinidad and Tobago remained difficult,\" said the report released on Friday by the State Department. The report also said the majority of drugs smuggled through T&T borders ended up, not in the US, but in other territories, including Europe, due to \"direct international flights to Europe as well as the ease of flow within the Caribbean and to Western Africa.\" The report also said illegal drugs were being smuggled out on yachts, air and sea cargo, or by couriers, and through the use of drug swallowers, which was on the rise. One of the illegal drugs being smuggled through T&T borders was heroin, and local authorities fear that this narcotic could add to the nation's drug problem and fuel even more gangland violence. Police believe heroin has already been the cause of the murder of one major drug dealer, Merlin 'Kojo' Allamby, who was shot dead last July. Last year, just over 27 kilogrammes of heroin were seized by lawmen, the largest amount ever seized locally. Local street value for heroin averages at $600,000 a kilogramme compared with $400,000 for a kilogramme of cocaine. In September last year, National Security Minister Martin Joseph suggested that heroin could soon become the nation's next drug epidemic. \"We're starting to see an increase in the transhipment of heroin coming through this country because I understand heroin fetches a much better price than cocaine,\" Joseph had said in Parliament. \"When cocaine first started transhipping through this country, you know what was the reaction of law enforcement Trinidadians and Tobagonians don't use cocaine, so what is the big thing Failing to realise that changes occur,\" Joseph said then. \"Back then cocaine didn't used to be accompanied by guns. People weren't using it so as a result there wasn't any rivalry. And then other things started to develop. They started to come with the guns, stayed, they started to use cocaine as payment and then it started to stay in the society and create problems. \"I have said to law enforcement, we must not make the same mistake that we made with cocaine. And I understand that heroin is a drug, the consequences of which is even worse than cocaine, so that we have to be very vigilant,\" Joseph said. While there have been no heroin busts for the year, officers attached to the Organised Crime, Narcotics and Firearms Bureau say that smugglers are \"always creative in the way they evade law enforcement.\" Heroin smuggling first began showing up in Trinidad and Tobago in 2000 with the seizure of a little over half a kilogramme in a police raid. Narcotics officers said they saw an increase in heroin smuggling in 2003. Between 2003 and beginning of 2005, police, mainly the Organised Crime, Narcotics and Firearms Bureau, seized a reported 39.275 kilogrammes of heroinworth about $23.6 million. The United States State Department, in its 2006 drug report, said that a total of 15.58 kilogrammes of heroin were seized in Trinidad in 2005. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/not-holding-our-breath/article_82031124-1e1d-582e-a6d3-8c83fd236d23.html", "TITLE": " Not holding our breath ", "DATE": "Aug 24, 2013 ", "CONTENT": "The CIC football team in action. The CIC football team in action. No one can disagree with the series of initiatives that form the substance of the collaboration between the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition on the issue of crime in East Port of Spain. While many of the proposed measures are hardly new, having been bandied about for years, the cooperation between the rival parties does indeed bring a new element into the equation. On the basis that two heads are a lot better than one, the public will hope to be spared the missteps that have tended to accompany the Peoples Partnership Governments implementation of strategies. The approach outlined by both leaders suggests a multifaceted strategy designed to streamline the management systems of the police service, enhance its material and human resources and tighten the criminal justice system. While on paper, it all sounds very useful, raising our hopes at this stage would be premature. If we sound a little jaded, it is because none of these strategies is new. It has long been clear that we do not have an effective system for developing and selecting the best candidate for Commissioner. We also already know that there are no shortcuts to a fully resourceful Police Service with enough people and equipment. Even so, providing more and better-equipped cars are more of the same, as is the plan to train and involve Special Reserve Police officers. If they didnt know it before, the disaster of the Defence Amendment Bill should have taught the Government that it would have been better off working to fill the large number of vacancies in the Police Service instead of trying to change the law to allow the precepting of soldiers. The idea of tightening the law to better protect witnesses and to review the anti-gang legislation and the Bail Act speak more to improving weak legislation than to developing new strategy. While all of these initiatives are important, the question is whether they will be enough to bring crime under control and to turn the situation around. The dimensions of the problem of crime are so broad and deep, that no one approach will inspire confidence. This is where one would have expected the Ryan Committees plan on crime to guide the way. Unfortunately, given its very limited insight into the problem, the plan has provided little guidance to the Governments effort. The proposed plan for the redevelopment of East Port of Spain is another useful component in a more sustainable effort against crime. However, in the context of daily murders, a medium-term plan does not offer the immediate relief that we all seek. From whatever angle the problem is contemplated, a top priority now must be to get guns out of the hands of those caught up in the crime wave and, even more importantly, to disrupt the supply of guns and drugs at the source. Rounding up youngsters by the scores cuts no ice with a public that is still waiting to catch Mr Big. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/on-captains-bridge-the-big-fisherman/article_cd5ed3bb-7f91-5c75-af92-cdf6062d8b33.html", "TITLE": " On captains bridge: The big fisherman ", "DATE": "Jan 24, 2014 ", "CONTENT": " Trinidad, if not also Tobago had the feel of one big crime scene last week, as local and US gumshoes, shadowed by reporters, poked around and sniffed a trail felt to be hot. Well, hotter than usual in this T&T, where crime business is regularly left abruptly unfinished, and mysteries lie strewn around like long-time children's unopened wonder bags. One bag whose contents stirred wonder two weeks ago was found in the trunk of a Gold Honda Civic parked in a Sea Lots police holding area. Other police, acting on \"tip-off\", swooped down on the area, opened the car trunk, and discovered 55 kilogrammes of ganja. \"The officers said they believed officers of the Stolen Vehicles Unit were part of the ploy to smuggle the drugs undetected,\" the Guardian reported. Jealous rivalries, the report implied, pitted police against police. But so far from identifying potential to be exploited, this story line, it seemed, only stilled a sense of wonder. Which is to say, T&T can expect to hear little or nothing more about ownership of and responsibility for 55 kilogrammes of ganja stashed in a car allegedly under guard by some police. The officers blessed with the tip-off were not inspired to stake out the joint, and await the furtive arrival of claimants to the ganja wonder bag. Civilian second-guessers might have seen in Sea Lots the promise of a \"sting\" operation to bust drug traffickers and their presumably police collaborators. But the story began and ended there and then, as prematurely as that related story of an unnamed officer defaming identifiable officers in the Stolen Vehicle Unit. And T&T preserved unexpended its sense of wonder for the next jolting episode in the progression of bizarre flashes and incomprehensible out-turns. Ganja seized in the Sea Lots non-bust could be expected to figure in one of the police-beloved photo ops showing officers posed smugly around tables on which drugs and guns, captured like booty, are neatly arrayed. Evidently, nobody, at any level of command in the Police Service, sees this practice of dumb show-and-tell as counter-productively mindless. So it continues, representing unconvincing efforts to portray police as high-achieving performers. The rest of us conclude the cheesy media exposure must be what the beat officers want and need, and we are often loath to begrudge them. Nor are the police really defenceless. \"Every time something goes wrong, you call police officers,\" said acting Inspector Anand Ramesar, head of the Police Association. \"And they continue to be burnt-out.\" Ag Insp Ramesar said at a time, earlier this month, when so much seemed to be going wrong, when so often fearful need arose to call the police. But so far from signalling anything like rising to the occasion of greatest law enforcement need, their association chief instead lowered expectations of their \"burnt-out\" incapacities. By the time the $644 million cocaine cache had been uncovered in Norfolk, bearing a T&T stamp of origin, we here had got the disheartening message that our local police were doing the best they could. If no prospect appeared of raising their game to the challenge level of 1.8 murders a day, the import and export of cargoes of canned cocaine were indisputably beyond their reach. For a long moment, no one appeared manning the captain's bridge of the law enforcement ship. Against Police Service Commission attempts to excoriate him publicly, Acting Commissioner Stephen Williams boasted only of his \"thick skin\". The law enforcement function was thus prepared for takeover by National Security Minister Gary Griffith. This coincided with the arrival of DEA agents, in the gathering momentum of investigative business left unfinished with the Norfolk bust of T&T-origin cocaine. Mr Griffith began to sound like a man fully armed and empowered to track the drug trafficking beast to its lair, wherever that might be. \"Regardless of who it is, or how high it goes,\" he said, flexing political muscle never before showed, \"I will do all I can to ensure that the persons are brought to justice.\" If T&T had needed a sheriff, this suddenly sounded like him. If the sheriff needed a posse, DEA agents, swarming all over, appeared to make up the man-hunting combination of men on horseback. Shortly, Mr Griffith was signalling that the allies\u2014the T&T Minister and the US DEA agents\u2014needed no others. In words both fearless and warlike, he said: \"We want to ensure that no other ministers in the Cabinet know what we are doing...because we don't want them to tip off someone who might be a friend of these people and then they disappear.\" Overnight, the former Army captain had been promoted to Cabinet field marshal, reporting only to the Prime Minister. It had come to that: Kamla Persad-Bissessar was urgently drawing from options in reserve. As T&T, and the rest of the government watched from the gallery, Gary Griffith, with his Yankee supporting cast, had been summoned to save the day. At last, guided once-overs of the T&T crime scene were expected to yield results in a haul of high-end wrongdoers. The big fish, everyone prayed, would meet their match in Big Fisherman Griffith.
