{"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/opinion/my-crime-plan/article_1711db70-47b5-5521-a528-fc08344babfe.html", "TITLE": " My crime plan ", "DATE": "Dec 18, 2016 ", "CONTENT": "I cannot leave the crime scene after apportioning blame for the crisis to the politicians and the police but not fingering the even more culpable culprits\u2014dysfunctional families and communities that are breeding grounds and safe havens for criminals. The police, more than the politicians, form the thin blue line that is supposed to stop the criminals from overwhelming the law-abiding population. It is what they are paid to do, although you would think otherwise when you encounter elements in the service who believe their uniforms empower them to abuse the citizenry, who embody that difficult-to-define Trini trait \u2014 \u201choggish\u201d. But whatever their faults, they are not, and cannot be, the first line of defence against crime and criminals. Let me explain my reasoning. If there were no crime, no criminals or lawbreakers, would we need the police I think not. I don't want to get into a philosophical debate on crime and criminality, or a religious argument about sin being an intrinsic part of human existence. I simply argue that if the entire society comprised only law-abiding citizens who treated each other with respect, who adhered to moral principles and ethical standards, then there would be no crime, hence no need for the police or prisons or the judiciary. Such utopia does not exist, however. Crime is universal and criminality is a dominant feature of societies such as ours. As so many scribes and crusaders against crime have noted, human beings are not born criminals. Sometime between birth and maturity, something or things happen that alter the minds, the values, the behaviour of certain people, stripping them of their conscience, which is the key to their entering the netherworld of crime. These changes occur in their homes, in their communities, in the environment in which they are nurtured in their formative years. Let me make it clear that while most of the criminals we get to know come from depressed districts, the shaping of the criminal mind, the stripping of the conscience that eventually leads to callous disregard for human lives, straddles societal stratifications. We are conditioned to focus on the bandits and heartless murderers who emerge from the slums, punks who believe that society owes them a living, nay, a lifestyle of \u201cbling\u201d and consumerism that they will grab by the barrel of a gun. Justifiably, we condemn the parents and communities that mass-produce these murderers, that grant them immunity from the already amputated arm of the law. Case in point: the men who murdered a WASA worker on the Powder Magazine compound in Cocorite last week are known to many residents there\u2014of that I am certain. But they won't give such information to the police (who may also know their identities). A few are fearful for their lives. Most don't give a damn. It matters not that an innocent worker lost his life, that they are harbouring a killer or ten who will likely strike again and again. But you know what WASA workers can strike back by refusing to service the complex, by creating a stoppage that will render Powder Magazine dry and stink and let it stay that way until the community hands over every criminal, not just one murderer. T&TEC, TSTT and cable television companies whose employees have been similarly targeted in other \u201chot spots\u201d can do likewise, exact retribution, force such dens to purge the criminal elements or suffer a boycott of essential services. Harsh, you say Yes. Illegal That, too. Innocent paying for the guilty They always do. As a veteran protester from the 1970s when we would target the root sources of the different issues with vocal- and placard-force, I am not impressed with powder puff protests in St Clair and similar enclaves. They achieve nothing other than assuage the guilt-by-indifference of a few people. If you must protest in such upscale districts, target the residences of the other criminal classes\u2014the importers of arms, ammunition and drugs, the price gougers, the banker-bandits, the medical and legal mafia, contractors and politicians who plunder the Treasury\u2026need I name more Don't mourn crime victims; organise, in large numbers, lay siege to the dens of crime across the country, in fact, shut down the damn country, everything\u2014utilities, industries, commercial enterprises\u2014and do not reopen it until the guns are surrendered and the criminals are behind bars\u2014no-collar, blue-collar, white-collar, all colours. Sure, many people will suffer, but aren't they suffering now Hell, some leaders might be arrested, jailed, even shot by criminals-in-and-out-of-uniforms. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/caribbean-struggles-to-stem-drug-trade/article_60d3a8bd-a2df-5be8-aba8-f80ca6f7d631.html", "TITLE": " Caribbean struggles to stem drug trade ", "DATE": "Dec 18, 2013 ", "CONTENT": "As night descended on the Caribbean on October 17, a US Coast Guard patrol aircraft spied something suspicious in the seas south of St Croix, one of the many beautiful specks of land that make up the US Virgin Islands: a 30-foot speedboat with three people aboard, loaded with bales and slicing through the waves toward Puerto Rico. A Coast Guard cutter and a specialised pursuit boat were dispatched from Puerto Rico to intercept the speedboat. Before dawn had broken, the coastguardsmen boarded and found more than a tonne of cocaine, with a wholesale value of more than US$34 million. The Coast Guard was thrilled at the haul, hailing the \"complex and dangerous operation\" undertaken in the dead of night. But it was a rare triumph. US and regional law enforcement agencies have been struggling to stem a resurgent tide of drugs flowing through the Caribbean. After a relatively calm two decades, during which Mexico emerged as the dominant smuggling point for trafficking drugs into the US, local and international officials say the Caribbean is once again becoming an important transit route, as cartels take advantage of the region's economic problems. Criminals are reactivating old operations in the archipelago or beefing up existing ones in places such as the Dominican Republic. The US Drugs Enforcement Administration (DEA) estimates that 14 per cent of all cocaine smuggled into the US in the first half of the year came via the Caribbean\u2014twice the rate of 2012. \"It's acute when you consider that the overall flow [into the US] is down,\" says Vito Guarino, DEA special agent in charge of Caribbean operations. It is still a far cry from the 1980s, when up to 75 per cent of the cocaine seized between South America and the US was taken in the Caribbean, according to the UN Office on Drugs and Crime. The unremitting flow of cocaine into Florida in particular inspired cultural touchstones like the movie Scarface and Miami Vice, the US television series. But the recent surge still worries US and Caribbean officials, who fear the region is acutely vulnerable to traffickers. Many countries are trying to cope with a protracted economic downturn and mounting debts, which are forcing governments to hack away at budgets and pushing up unemployment. \"You're unemployed and starving, and someone offers you $1,000 to take a go-fast boat full of drugs to the US. What would we do in this situation\" Guarino says. The region is also paying the price of successes elsewhere. Analysts say one of the big reasons why cartels are re-establishing themselves in the Caribbean is the clear security improvement in Mexico. As police \"squeeze the narco balloon\" there, it swells in the tropical islands to the east, according to Daniel Sachs, a Mexico-based analyst at Control Risks, a consultancy. The impact is invidious. Cartels frequently ally themselves with local gangs on islands like Trinidad, paying for protection and smuggling services with guns and drugs. That feeds domestic drug abuse and exacerbates already high crime rates, as heavily armed local gangs fight for lucrative turf and cartel contracts. These gangs are the cause of the region's extreme murder rates, argues Owen Ellington, head of Jamaica's police force. Moreover, drug money can buy many friends in a region, where even an army general or senior police officer will often make only a few thousand dollars a month, and political donations and spending usually go unreported, activists and diplomats say. Security officials say the Dominican Republic is the main transshipment point for drugs bound for the US and Europe, due to the cultural and linguistic ties with the cocaine-producing countries in South and Central America. However, smaller statelets like St Kitts and Nevis, which simply cannot afford to defend their coasts, are the ones that have arguably suffered the most from the increase in trafficking. Ralph Gonsalves, Prime Minister of St Vincent and the Grenadines, estimates about half his country's murders are directly tied to the drug trade. \"The bulk of the drugs is for the US and European markets, but [the traffickers] bring guns with them,\" he complains. US and international officials are keenly aware of the resurgent danger, and have launched a number of programmes in response. The US government established a Caribbean Basin Security Initiative (CBSI) in 2009 to provide countries with technical assistance, equipment and training to combat crime and drug smuggling. This includes setting up detection-dog units, improving prisons, providing cargo scanners, polygraphs and interceptor boats, and sharing more information with local security forces. The CBSI has spent US$263 million on various initiatives since it was established in 2009, according to the US state department. Local politicians say it has helped to improve their capabilities, but argue it is trifling compared with the scale of the problem.\"The resources deployed under the Caribbean Basin Security Initiative can be described as a drop in the bucket,\" said Barbados Prime Minister Freundel Stuart. Optimism is in short supply. Even if the US and regional law enforcement succeed in staunching the drug flow, this could paradoxically lead to an increase in violence, as local gangs and cartels fight over a smaller pie, notes Amado de Andrs, the UNODC's regional representative. He points out that bloodshed in Jamaica increased dramatically even as it became a less important transit point for cocaine in the 1990s. Mexico has seen a similar trend more recently. In many countries, there appears to be resignation that drugs trafficking will always be a challenge, and concern the problem will inevitably worsen in the coming years. \"We're right in the middle of the world's biggest producer and consumer of drugs,\" observes Bernardo Vega, a former Dominican central bank governor and ambassador to the US. \"If only they could grow cocaine in the Rocky Mountains,\" he sighs. \u2022 The Financial Times spent two weeks reporting across the Caribbean, travel funded in part by the Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting, to explore the impact of the region's economic downturn. \u2014FT.com TWO videos which show minors engaged in sexual acts with adults are now engaging the attenti\u2026 The prisoner who escaped from the Maximum Security Prison on Thursday, has been found. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/griffith-apologises-to-the-judiciary/article_ae7b0faa-4715-57a9-902d-6aa2944b834e.html", "TITLE": " Griffith apologises to the Judiciary ", "DATE": "Nov 27, 2011 ", "CONTENT": "Gary Griffith, National Security adviser to Prime Minister Kamla Persad-Bissessar, has apologised to the Judiciary. However, Griffith said his comments, which were made during an interview with a foreign journalist, were not aimed at this country's Judiciary as he was speaking on a global context. \"At no time did I mean to state or imply that our Judiciary has been the cause, is responsible or is involvedin any manner in criminal involvement, especially as I have no such knowledge, and if any such perception or view was derived from my statement, I do humbly apologise, as I hold our judicial system in the highest regard,\" said Griffith in a statement yesterday. Last Friday, Griffith was quoted in an interview with the United Kingdom's Channel Four which featured this country's State of Emergency. Griffith was asked by Channel Four reporter Seyi Rhodes: \"It's probably no surprise to you to hear that every person I speak to in Trinidad, when I ask them where the drugs and the guns come from, they tell me that the ports, the customs authorities, the Coast Guard and the police are a 100 per cent involved in the trafficking of drugs and guns. Why are you not focussing on that\" Griffith replied: \"Every country in the world will have corrupt police officers, will have corrupt persons in the Judiciary, will have corrupt politicians. That is not an avenue to call a State of Emergency. We needed a State of Emergency to stop law abiding citizens of this country from being killed.\" This comment by Griffith prompted the Judiciary to issue a statement on Sunday. The statement by the Judiciary indicated that any reasonable person after listening to Griffith would conclude that the Judiciary is corrupt and tied in with the importation of guns and drugs to this country. In its statement, the Judiciary questioned whether Griffith was in possession of evidence on persons in the Judiciary which enables him to so \"confidently and poignantly\" link them with the importation of drugs and guns in the country in the current scenario of a State of Emergency in Trinidad and Tobago. The Judiciary challenged Griffith to justify his statements. Yesterday, in response to the Judiciary's criticisms and concerns, Griffith issued a statement where he explained his position. Griffith said the reporter had questioned why was the Government not going after the \"big fish\", referring to the persons in law enforcement agency and criminal justice system who could use their position and influence to assist in the major criminal acts being successful. \"What he (reporter) was referring to as persons in the law enforcement agency and criminal justicesystem who could use their position and influence to assist in the major criminal acts being successful,\" said Griffith. \"My response was to show that a State of Emergency is not designed to deal with such aspects, as it involves primarily crime prevention, which is hard targeting, patrols, and deterrents,\" he added. \"I stated that such reports and accusations have been known worldwide, as every country would be involved from time to time with allegations of such matters, including the involvement of politicians, law enforcement officers and even the Judiciary, but these matters have to be dealt with another level, and not specifically during a State of Emergency,\" said Griffith. His statement, he said, was based on what takes place globally and in general, and not in any way to include the Judiciary in Trinidad and Tobago. He noted that there was a conference held in Vienna several years ago, dealing with judicial corruption, and the causes and economic consequences. He noted further that the Global Corruption Report in 2007 also dealt with judicial corruption based on findings from Transparency International whereby certain countries have been accused of such acts. \"Thankfully, our Judiciary has never been accused or has been involved in such acts, andwe should pride ourselves with this fact,\" said Griffith. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/a-breakdown-in-trust/article_313cda90-c8c0-5797-afdd-dbf10a803254.html", "TITLE": " A breakdown in trust ", "DATE": "Jan 3, 2010 ", "CONTENT": "night of drinking: Shedrick Toppin night of drinking: Shedrick Toppin IT could all be summed up in a single word trust. One of the major conclusions reached in the latest report on crime in Trinidad and Tobago, carried exclusively in yesterday's Sunday Express, has stated that the problem of gun-related crime will not go away. Not at least anytime soon. As the author of the report put it, \"steps by the government to bolster law enforcement and curb smuggling are hobbled by a worsening of civic attitudes.\" By this he meant simply that citizens have been refusing to repose faith in the ability of the authorities to reverse the trend, one that has been intensifying and going upward for more than a decade now. \"Citizens are downright cynical about the ability of the state to reverse the mayhem caused by guns and gangs,\" the report's author concluded. As sources for the information used in compiling this report, little of which comes as brand new to the people of Trinidad and Tobago and those paying close attention to current developments here, the report relied on conversations with and data provided by an array of individuals including those in the media, in the police service itself, in some of the country's non-governmental organisations and university professors.One significant finding this report makes about the local situation is the complexity involved in the crime problem, with its roots deep into the culture of gangs and drugs that has sprung up over the years. Such complexity is illustrated by what the author described in his finding that \"a variety of forces stand arrayed against efforts at improvement\". Weeks before he was to have been granted a third extension last month on his tenure as the country's Acting Commissioner of Police, James Philbert provided his own insight into the central theme of this latest report. He had disclosed that some 42,000 citizens had submitted applications for firearms licences. Such a disclosure would have presented perhaps the most graphic clue to what this new report has revealed, that public trust in the ability of the state and its related agencies in crime fighting has plummeted. The job to rebuild it continues to prove extremely difficult, compounded by the general lack of confidence which large sections of the public have in the integrity of police officers. With criminal activity of one kind or another among individual officers, or groups of them acting in concert, a regular feature of media reports, such attitudes among members of the public only harden by the day. Constant pleadings by successive Commissioners and other leading police officials for public co-operation in the provision of information and intelligence to investigating officers have not been bearing sufficient fruit. This is despite whatever the level of success that is being claimed, even as reports such as the one in focus do more damage to such claims, as well as to the country's standing. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/trini-to-the-bone/article_1b3adad9-fa34-5cbf-9cb9-46f4e131621d.html", "TITLE": " TRINI TO THE BONE ", "DATE": "May 5, 2014 ", "CONTENT": "Flashback September 2009: Dana Seetahal SC celebrates 30 years of practising law during a reception at her El Dorado Chambers, St Vincent Street, Port of Spain. \u0097Photo: CURTIS CHASE Flashback September 2009: Dana Seetahal SC celebrates 30 years of practising law during a reception at her El Dorado Chambers, St Vincent Street, Port of Spain. \u0097Photo: CURTIS CHASE Twice as he gave the tribute to Dana Seetahal yesterday, Independent Senator Anthony Vieira almost cried, but then he composed himself and held it together. Seetahal's assassination sets a dangerous and destabilising precedent, Vieira, an attorney, said in the Senate. Seetahal served as an independent senator from 2002 to 2010. The mood in the Senate was overwhelmingly sombre and heavy as the Senate paid tribute to Seetahal. There was one theme throughout the tributes\u2014that her death was not simply the murder of another person by the hands of criminals, but represented an irreplaceable and significant loss. She literally gave her talent, her commitment, her love and sadly her life, to this country. The sentiment expressed by those who spoke was she was married to her dedication to Trinidad and Tobago\u2014a true public servant, whether she was part of the civil service or not. An emotional Vieira said: \"This premeditated and carefully executed assassination goes beyond the murder of a defenceless woman\u2014it represents an attack on our justice system and an attack on law and order itself. \"It calls for a frank assessment of the existing deficiencies in our criminal justice system; and our law enforcement and security capabilities, particularly bearing in mind that Trinidad and Tobago falls within a network of drug-trafficking and international criminal activity (including gun-running, money-laundering and drug related crimes). \"And it calls us to consider whether our law enforcement architecture has the requisite capability to effectively address this latest form of terror tactics and the non-traditional types of crime.\" He added: \"We can no longer proceed in our customary, relaxed manner. We need to restore public confidence and reduce the feelings of insecurity and disquiet which now grips the nation. \"Among other things, we need to upgrade our security laws, develop our intelligence-gathering capabilities, and allocate the necessary resources to protect those serving at the front line and who may be at risk; in particular judges, magistrates and prosecutors handling high-profile criminal cases. \"I stand with the Police Complaints Authority director Gillian Lucky in demanding action from the State to protect them.\" Vieira continued: \"We have become adjusted and have grown to accept the deterioration of our criminal justice system. Dana's death must serve as a call to arms to all who would establish the rule of law and justice in the affairs and men.\" He added that this was a solemn moment in the course of the country's struggle for law and order. He said it needed to be recognised that \"we can't have a free, safe and stable society if we lack an overarching strategy to cope with the crime and security challenges\". {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/update-overdue-on-drug-gang-busting/article_ac706ecb-6be1-5b5e-860c-2e3611f339e6.html", "TITLE": " Update overdue on drug gang-busting ", "DATE": "May 13, 2012 ", "CONTENT": " Five months after the end of the State of Emergency, with murders more than one a day, the year 2011 is by comparison already looking like the good old days. Back in August 2011, the shock of multiple gangland killings had jolted the government's into triggering the emergency, itself a shock response. The emergency entailed a curfew, and the roll-out of heavy, \"zero-tolerance\", policing. It also engendered a sense of the balance of power being shifted in favour of the forces of law and order. The effect was to depress (but not extinguish) gang activity, to disrupt related criminal pattern and practice, and to hold down the murder rate. Sighs of relief naturally arose. But not all fingers could stay crossed in hope that such advances in the \"war on crime\" could be sustained past the emergency. Even during the emergency, the sweeps and swoops to enforce the new anti-gang laws ominously backfired. If the police were over-zealous in making arrests based on the untested anti-gang legislation, the DPP was to the same degree unmoved by any sense of urgency to put alleged gangsters before the courts, if only to test the legislation. No \"silver bullet\" solution, it was proved, was available for the defeat of drug-related gangsterism and associated murderous violence. By early December, when the emergency ended, no viable \"crime plan\" was in sight to wrest the initiative away from the shadowy axis of drug runners and their hired guns. Last weekend, fatal gunplay in northern St James, evidently combined the elements of gang rivalry, illegal drugs and effortless acquisition of firearms. Over that weekend, too, police interdiction in Arima yielded $15 million worth of ganja together with an Uzi submachine gun, a Remington repeater shotgun, and related ammunition. Another emergency is unthinkable. Certainly, however, it is timely to reassess law enforcers' preparedness for confronting gangs. In last week's Business Express, the Trinidad and Tobago Chamber of Industry and Commerce spoke up as one critical interest group querying what law enforcement progress has been made since December. Have the police and the DPP come together with a workable plan of action To what extent are those two vital agencies still working at cross purposes, thereby disserving the national interest in gang, drug, and gun crime containment If the anti-gang legislation has been shown to need amendment, when will Parliament be asked to do so If the police were seen to need specialised training, what has taken place to improve their approaches toward gang violence and the relentless rise in murders In all this, a finger of accountability points in one inescapable directionto the leadership and management of the police. Commissioner Dwayne Gibbs must let the country know where gang-busting and the defeat of criminal bloodletting fit into his perspectives and operations called 21st Century policing. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/rid-the-police-of-roughnecks/article_a31a6fa4-40a4-5185-b682-b96e20e52d6f.html", "TITLE": " Rid the police of roughnecks ", "DATE": "Mar 9, 2012 ", "CONTENT": "THE murder rate ticks along, one-a-day, like some health supplement or prescription drug, with the arrests rate lagging behind the body count, as has always been the case. Robberies and burglaries, many of them as brazen as ever, CCTV recordings notwithstanding, gallop at an alarming pace. Acts of violence, threats that could turn crimson (as in blood), and entire communities cowed by gun-toting bullies, now a national pastime, go mostly unreported, except, perhaps, to Ian Alleyne and Crime Watch. Why The police have more serious matters to attend to. The daily media briefings, for example, a feature that emerged during the State of Emergency, an exercise in numbers crunching, has morphed into a 21st Century policing initiative. Image is important. Stars are manufactured. Oh, I almost forgot. There was that all-important issue of executing a warrant on an errant watchman who failed to pay child maintenance. Summon the troops. Jeep-loads of armed-to-the-teeth police officersand dont forget the battering-ram. Or the resident Jet-Li. Move in during the still of the night. The target is armed and dangerous. What is happening in the Police Service Is this a case where brawn still trumps brains Where thugs-in-uniforms are symbols of police prowess I hate to hurl yet another missile at besieged Commissioner Dwayne Gibbs, but such is the burden of command. I think that the Canadian has been unfairly targeted in instances...a scapegoat of sorts. But given his experience, he must have known that he was in for a rough ride as CoP in a service that is riddled with rogues, a force that remains steeped in the culture of thuggery, and a country in which tolerance translates into a license to be lawless. As is normal when columnists or others in the public make these observations, we qualify them by saying that many police officers execute their duties in a very professional manner, in accordance with their oaths of office. Sadly, all too often good policing by the many is overshadowed by the ugly actions of the few. What is worrisome is that the latter not only attract public attention, but their misconduct stands out like a big blot on the image of the entire Service. Last Wednesday night, a number of them descended on the Laventille compound of the Transport and Industrial Workers Union. Their mission, it seems, was to arrest a night watchman who had an outstanding warrant for not paying child maintenance money as ordered by a court. You would think that one or two officers, maybe armed with batons, would suffice. Instead, what ought to have been a routine exercise turned into a display of thuggery that has always existed in the Service, but which, with the advent of CCTV cameras, is now available live and alive for public consumption. And what the public saw was not nice. It was almost as if a nearby gang had descended on the unions headquarters, bent on mayhem and murder. The police action, a wanton abuse of their powers, was ugly...and thats putting it mildly. In the aftermath, they left a trail of destruction of property and many unanswered questions. Who authorised the raid Why Did the police not have serious crimes to arrest rather than batter a wayward father and in the process violate a trade unions headquarters The frequency with which incidents of police brutality and abuse of power have occurred is cause for grave concern. Two media houses have felt the full force of what I can only term rank stupidity on the part of officers. Workers at Trinidad Cement Ltd, conducting a legal strike, were also subjected to police boorishness. Many other incidents within recent times, some of them now sub judice, call into question the kind of training these officers undergo. It is not that police abuse of power is something new. Deviant elements in what was then appropriately named the Police Force used to bruise, batter, and sometimes kill civilians. Indeed, even soldiers were guilty of such misdeeds, although most times such incidents were retaliatoryas happened in Carenage in 1963. In recent times, though, soldiers have been accused of what I dub abuse of uniform. However, military justice is swift and often severe, not constrained by the niceties of civil or criminal law. The Commanding Officer of the Regiment (and the Coast Guard) wields immense power: he could jail and dishonourably discharge a junior officer or soldier, with loss of benefits, in short order. With regard to police abuse, what is different is that nowadays, with monitoring devices installed just about everywhere, the miscreants are easily identified and exposed to public scrutiny. How the Service deals with guilty officers is quite another matter. In many instances the authorities simply transfer the miscreants to stations located in rural districtswhich, in effect, amounts to transferring the problem, not resolving it in the best interests of the Service and the aggrieved parties. Or, some are suspended from duty with full pay for years. In rare cases, rogue officers face criminal charges, and even then they enjoy the protective cloak of their colleagues when they appear in court. With the image of the Service in near-tatters, the public can only hope that the high command and the judicial authorities act swiftly to restore confidence in the police. In the wake of the TIWU incident, we expect to see heads rolland not from one station to another. It is time to get rid of the roughnecks who bring the Service into disrepute. It was refreshing to hear Association president, Sergeant Anand Ramesar, call for a thorough investigation into the incident, and action on the findings. The public expects nothing less. See Page 8. \u0097Photo: ROBERTO CODALLO concerned: Justice Minister Herbert Volney looks on as Police Complaints Authority chairman Gillian Lucky speaks during yesterday's news conference at the Ministry of Justice in Port of Spain. See Page 8. \u0097Photo: ROBERTO CODALLO MINISTER of Justice and Member of Parliament for St Joseph Herbert Volney is describing the police killing of Mt D'Or resident Atiba Duncan as a homicide. He said yesterday his assertion is supported by the findings of the pathologist who performed the post-mortem and the account of eyewitnesses that 26-year-old Duncan was shot in his back at close range. Volney is also calling for the police officers involved to be immediately placed on suspension, pending the outcome of investigations into the incident. Volney was speaking at a news conference at the Ministry of Justice located at Tower C of the Waterfront Centre in Port of Spain. Also present was chairman of the Police Complaints Authority (PCA) Gillian Lucky, who said she had to remind Police Commissioner Dwayne Gibbs of the established protocol, which requires that the PCA be informed in a timely manner when incidents, such as the Duncan killing, occur. Eyewitnesses to the April 4 killing said Duncan, a footballer, was liming and smoking marijuana outside a shop at Mt D'Or Road, Champs Fleurs, when police approached and he ran. Residents claimed one of the two police officers held on to Duncan, who was unarmed, but he wrested himself free and took off before being shot. St Joseph Police reported that an attempt was made to execute an outstanding warrant for drug trafficking on Duncan when he ran off, pulled out a pistol and was about to pull the trigger when he was shot. \"I am very, very concerned that something is very wrong with the method of training of our police officers, especially the constables who are entrusted with high-powered rifles,\" Volney said. \"(The Duncan killing) is not the only such incident in our country in the last two years. According to statistics from the Crime And Problem Analysis Branch (CAPA), in 2010 there were 52 killings by police officers. In 2011, there were 43 killings. Out of these 43 killings, three were classified as murder. \"Any killing of a citizen by a police officer must be with lawful justification. Police officers who are armed with firearms, while they have a function to do, they must exercise great caution in carrying out their legitimate function. The use of a firearm, except in instances of obvious self-defence, is unjustifiable use and overuse of a lawful weapon.\" Volney said eyewitnesses readily admitted Duncan had a small quantity of marijuana in his possession which he tried to get rid of when the police arrived on the scene. \"(Based on the post-mortem report), this means that the deceased was shot by the police officer in his back as he was fleeing. From the reports at hand, this appears to be nothing short of a homicidal killing. I say this not just as an MP, but also as a former justice of the High Courtone who has presided over hundreds of criminal trials. \"This sort of behaviour by police officers will no longer be tolerated by the Ministry of Justice. We will not sit by idly and allow this to take place. Atiba Duncan had weed and not a gun. And you don't kill a man in this country for being in possession of weed. That is the law.\" Volney also accused the police officers of failing in their duty when they returned to the area, not to take Duncan to the hospital, but to retrieve spent shells. He said they failed to preserve the scene of a crime. Asked about the plan of his Ministry to address other similar abuses of power, Volney said he has already raised the issue at the level of Cabinet. \"The Police Service at this time under the leadership of commander Dwayne Gibbs, or is it Dr Dwayne Gibbs, seems to be a service without leadership. It seems to be a service without a policy. It is a runaway service. And while I am not here to pound the police, because there are many good police officers, there are many in the Police Service who are too quick to draw the gun. The gun is a last resort. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/bhoe-help-affected-by-murders/article_37caebf3-596e-5fc3-9da3-e752629c5ce9.html", "TITLE": " Bhoe: Help 20,000 affected by murders ", "DATE": "Apr 3, 2013 ", "CONTENT": "\"serious problem\": Dr Bhoendradatt Tewarie \"serious problem\": Dr Bhoendradatt Tewarie Planning Minister Dr Bhoendradatt Tewarie made an impassioned plea for support of the bill to give Defence Force members police powers, saying it was necessary to deal with the crime scourge gripping this country. \"There can be no question that we need to deal strongly with crime. It is a serious problem in this country,\" said Tewarie in his contribution to the Defence and Police Complaints Authority Amendment Bill, 2013 at the Senate sitting, Tower D, International Waterfront Centre, Port of Spain, on Tuesday. More than 20,000 people, he said, in the past decade, from 2002 to date, had been affected by crime. Tewarie said more than 4,000 people were murdered, and this meant that there were 4,000 families left in grief. \"Just over 7,600 have felt a bullet or a cutlass or some blunt or sharp instrument on them, traumatising, again, 7,610 families; and rapes, incest and other sexual offences, over 7,800 cases, making it a total of 20,000 people who have been directly affected by crime in the form of murder, that is to say, they are dead and their families remain to mourn; wounding and shootings and, therefore, their families have had to live with the trauma; and rape, incest and other sexual offences, nearly 8,000, 7,800, and their families have also had to live with this experience,\" said Tewarie. The minister said the mental state of the people is being affected. \"What does the ripple effect of a murder in a family have on the people in the community in which that person lives, or in the people in the family that are connected to them, whether they live in the resident community or outside \"What is the impact of all of this on the people who are sexually molested and by the woundings and the shootings What is the impact What do you think happens to the society\" he asked. Not dealing with crime, Tewarie said, was creating a situation in which we had to perpetually live with this kind of condition, which was \"psychiatrically unacceptable\" for this small country. Tewarie said dealing with crime means lessening the trauma on people who have been affected like this over the last decade. He noted that as crime grows, the security industry in this country also grew, with just 7,000 law enforcement officers in the Police Service and just under 3,000 in the military service. Some 276 officers, he said, were at Immigration, 488 were deployed to Customs and Excise, and yet there were problems in the system which resulted in drugs and gun-running pervading the society. He noted further that recently, 75 women were before the court charged with soliciting for the purpose of prostitution. \"But the question I have to ask when they go to court is: how did they get here in the first place, and who brought them here So, these things could not happen if you had functional systems in the society. \"You could not have 75 women from foreign countries parading in the court in one shot, unless you had dysfunctional systems that allowed such numbers to accrue. \"And, therefore, we have a serious problem here, and the challenge really has come to us, being in charge of the State, of how you deal with these matters,\" said Tewarie. Crime, he said, must be dealt with in a multifaceted and multipronged approach. Tewarie said the legislation was a necessary part of the arsenal to deal with these challenges. \"I would like to make this appeal for support for this bill because this bill is not about militarisation; this bill is about getting a functional capability in a dysfunctional system to deal with dysfunctionality in criminal behaviour in this society. That is what we need to do, and we have got to deal with it while we deal with other things in the society,\" he said. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/murder-makes-sense/article_c287dfdd-f0b8-51b3-8aab-bb5534644d58.html", "TITLE": " Murder makes sense ", "DATE": "Nov 12, 2014 ", "CONTENT": "When it comes to murder, some stock phrases are always tossed around, like senseless killing, murdering innocent people, and all we could do is pray. The flawed ideas which these phrases reveal explain, in part, the failure to reduce the countrys homicide rate ten years after such crimes began to escalate. To start with, few killings are senseless. A senseless murder is one which has no pragmatic motive, and such murders are usually committed by psychopaths who kill purely for the pleasure of killing. Most murderers, however, have clear and understandable motives: usually, money or sexoften both. So, since the police themselves categorise most murders as gang- and/or drug-related, there are rational reasons for a certain category of young men to turn to these avenues in order to acquire resources and status. They have no other skills and, with an incompetent and corrupt police force, the risk of being caught is reasonably low. This is even truer of white-collar crime. Those persons who are criticised and condemned for fraud and corruption may be the target of calumny, but their lack of ethics has resulted in them being both rich and powerful. But non-murdering non-tiefing citizens have some indirect culpability as well. Even if the political system makes crime a rational economic choice for certain people, such political strategies would not be effective if they werent supported by cultural normsi.e. the moral values of the majority. And, generally speaking, it is people who claim to be most moral who have devoted the least thought to moral principles. Why should they, when they know what is moral and what is not It is therefore doubly foolish when journalists approach religious leaders for their views on crime. Apart from few if any of them having a background in criminology, crime is not a moral problem, but a problem of politics, economics, and ethics. Moral pronouncements therefore distract from real solutions. Once we start from the premise that most criminals are acting rationally, then solutions beyond strong-arm tactics and punishment can be formulated. So we have to ask why murders suddenly increased in 2003 My view is that this was a direct consequence of then-prime minister Patrick Manning trying to bribe gang leaders with URP monies to stop killing one another. But I may be wrong, and the increase may have been caused by other factors, such as drug dealers paying off their low-level distributors on the block with guns as well as money. In the latter case, the solution would be to stop the trafficking in guns. This, however, seems nigh impossible. The trade in cocaine and marijuana is too profitable for too many people, including many persons in official posts, for any counter-incentives to work. And if that is the case, then the only effective solution would be to reduce the drug dealers profits by decriminalising or legalising marijuana and cocaine. But people like Pastor Clive Dottin, who is viewed by influential persons as a crime-fighting expert, would oppose such a measure because they are more interested in pushing their groundless beliefs than in saving lives. The only viable long-term strategy therefore lies in changing attitudes, especially towards violence. There are four socio-political measures which are likely to have good effects in this regard: 1. banning corporal punishment; 2. abolishing capital punishment; 3. legalising abortions; and 4. giving homosexual persons the same human rights as heterosexual ones. These measures embody opposition to violence as a solution to problems, empowerment of poor women resulting in better child-care, and tolerance of difference. If such laws were passed, then this society could become a more enlightened and peaceful place before babies crying today become adults who kill tomorrow. kevin.baldeosingh@zoho.com TWO videos which show minors engaged in sexual acts with adults are now engaging the attenti\u2026 The prisoner who escaped from the Maximum Security Prison on Thursday, has been found. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/gunfire-kills-young-children-daily-in-us/article_c44706f0-46a8-5fcc-a54b-2b3bf35fa2b9.html", "TITLE": " Gunfire kills young children daily in US ", "DATE": "Dec 24, 2012 ", "CONTENT": "Pan Jammers \u0097Photo: Dave Persad KILLED IN JULY: This undated photo provided by Robert Sullivan shows Veronica Moser-Sullivan, the youngest person slain in the July 20 attack that left 12 dead and dozens wounded during the Aurora theatre shootings. The National Rifle Association, the largest gun lobby in the United States, suggested shielding children from gun violence by placing an armed police officer in every school by the time classes resume in January. Pan Jammers \u0097Photo: Dave Persad KILLED IN JULY: This undated photo provided by Robert Sullivan shows Veronica Moser-Sullivan, the youngest person slain in the July 20 attack that left 12 dead and dozens wounded during the Aurora theatre shootings. The National Rifle Association, the largest gun lobby in the United States, suggested shielding children from gun violence by placing an armed police officer in every school by the time classes resume in January. l WASHINGTON Before 20 children were massacred at school by a gunman in Newtown, Connecticut, Luke Schuster, 6, was shot dead in New Town, North Dakota. Six-year-olds John Devine Jr and Jayden Thompson were similarly killed in Kentucky and Texas. Veronica Moser-Sullivan, 6, died in a mass shooting at a movie theatre in Aurora, Colorado, while 6-year-old Kammia Perry was slain by her father outside her Cleveland home, according to an Associated Press review of 2012 media reports. Yet there was no gunman on the loose when Julio Segura-McIntosh died in Tacoma, Washington. The 3-year-old accidentally shot himself in the head while playing with a gun he found inside a car. As he mourned with the families of Newtown, President Barack Obama said the US cannot accept such violent deaths of children as routine. But hundreds of young child deaths by gunfirewhether intentional or accidentalsuggest it might already have. Between 2006 and 2010, 561 children under 12 were killed by firearms, according to the FBI's most recent Uniform Crime Reports. The numbers each year are consistent: 120 in 2006; 115 in 2007; 116 in 2008, 114 in 2009 and 96 in 2010. The FBI's count does not include gun-related child deaths that authorities have ruled accidental. \"This happens on way too regular a basis and it affects families and communitiesnot at once, so we don't see it and we don't understand it as part of our national experience,\" said Daniel Webster, director of the Johns Hopkins Center for Gun Policy and Research. The true number of small children who died by gunfire in 2012 will not be known for a couple of years, when official reports are collected and dumped into a database and analysed. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention expects to release its 2011 count in the spring. In response to what happened in Newtown, the National Rifle Association, the nation's largest gun lobby, suggested shielding children from gun violence by putting an armed police officer in every school by the time classes resume in January. \"Politicians pass laws for gun-free school zones... They post signs advertising them and in doing so they tell every insane killer in America that schools are the safest place to inflict maximum mayhem with minimum risk,\" said NRA executive vice-president Wayne LaPierre. Webster said children are more likely to die by gunfire at home or in the street. They tend to be safer when they are in school, he said. None of the 61 deaths reviewed by The Associated Press happened at school. Children die by many other methods as well: violent stabbings or throat slashings, drowning, beating and strangulation. But the gruesome recounts of gun deaths, sometimes just a few paragraphs in a newspaper or on a website, a few minutes on television or radio, bear witness that firearms too, are cutting short many youngsters' lives. One week before the Newtown slayings, Alyssa Celaya, 8, bled to death after being shot by her father with a .38-calibre gun at the Tule River Indian Reservation in California.
